intro: Silene crassifolia subsp. crassifolia, commonly known as the broadleaf catchfly, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a member of the Caryophyllaceae family and is characterized by its upright growth habit and showy pink to reddish-purple flowers. The plant typically grows in dry, open habitats such as grasslands and rocky slopes. Its leaves are lance-shaped and often covered in fine hairs, while its stems are hairy and somewhat succulent. The species is adapted to arid environments and is often found in regions with low precipitation.
